FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:

The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Remove the trailing slash when formatting the tab fragment" (#9138) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The search result may point to a URL like this:
https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/

The existing approach appends the tab fragment like this:
https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/#versions-body-tab

This is to remove the trailing slash when formatting the tab fragment:
https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json#versions-body-tab

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Merge branch 'main' into dev" (#9131) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[A11y]Incorrect Aria attribute used on label" (#9134) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
URL:'
https://www.nuget.org/users/account/ForgotPassword
https://www.nuget.org/users/account/SignUp

The aria-required property is not allowed on html label elements.
Let's either find the correct property for label elements, or move the aria-required property to the text entry box.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]iFrame is not able to be tab navigated" (#9133) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
As part of an effort to fix tab ordering, we added a "tab-index=-1" property to the reCAPTCHA iframe.
This had the consequence of removing the entire content in the iframe from the tab order.
Changing this to tab-index=1 should enable a sensible tab order AND leave the iframe content in a tabbable state.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]Contrast of links on README tables is sometimes not high enough." (#9132) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11051729/171963165-f0f76f41-fed8-4d59-8490-1524165301fd.png)
Colour contrast of the Fancy Zones link is not high enough.
This is due to the table rendering with a non white background colour.

This will likely be an issue on all README pages that have links in tables.
Globally darkening our link colour should address this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ""Illegal characters in path" (Solution Directory)" (#11764) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Attempting a `nuget install` with an incorrect solution directory gives the cryptic error "Illegal characters in path." The first assumption is that there is a problem with the PATH environment variable, but [the line in question](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/f7208c454ebf18fc37b15fda3438d6a5ece6cdd7/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Commands/InstallCommand.cs#L115) combines the Solution Directory with ".nuget". This clue seems to indicate illegal characters in the solution directory, but the solutionDirectory specified on my command line is legal.

The real problem is that the solution is at `C:\repos\repo\src\Solution.sln`, but the specified solution directory is `C:\repos\repo\build\`. This is a legal path, so I assume that some other code has changed the path from the command line to something illegal, but the message doesn't give much help:
```
C:\repos\repo\build>"C:\repos\repo\build\/nuget.exe" install BuildTasks -verbosity detail -excludeVersion -version 2.3.1 -solutionDirectory "C:\repos\repo\build\"
NuGet Version: 6.1.0.106
Illegal characters in path.
System.ArgumentException: Illegal characters in path.
   at System.IO.Path.CheckInvalidPathChars(String path, Boolean checkAdditional)
   at System.IO.Path.Combine(String path1, String path2)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.InstallCommand.CalculateEffectiveSettings()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.InstallCommand.ExecuteCommandAsync()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Command.Execute()
   at NuGet.CommandLine.Program.MainCore(String workingDirectory, String[] args)
```

_Originally posted by @papeh in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8373#issuecomment-1104447279_

@chris1248 also suggests an improved message in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8373#issuecomment-656985569

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4586 improves the message.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "When restore raises an NU1301, build might fail with a `project.assets.json doesn't have a target for 'net6.0-windows10.0.19041.0` like error that's a red herring" (#11862) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: The real problem is that restore failed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: NuGet 6.2 incompatible with lock file from NuGet 6.1 - NU1101: Unable to find package" (#11851) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

NuGet 6.2

### Worked before?

NuGet 6.1

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Consider this csproj:

``` xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
	<PropertyGroup>
		<TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
		<RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>
	</PropertyGroup>
	<ItemGroup>
		<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data" Version="9.0.2.33" />
	</ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

1. Restore project with NuGet 6.1 `nuget.exe restore repro.csproj`. The lock file is:
``` json
{
  "version": 1,
  "dependencies": {
    "net6.0": {
      "Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[9.0.2.33, )",
        "resolved": "9.0.2.33",
        "contentHash": "gREfQl0/mh22+eV9h8PhCnAwNY5SJswLnUPxvxJwF6L2mhj5pMFMUSvlVke3Gpk94XCrBEyIgHJzFKDiMtA1aw=="
      }
    }
  }
}
```

3. Delete the obj\ directory. Restore project with NuGet 6.2. Receive error:
> NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages, nuget.org

Workaround - delete the lock file. The new lock file is:

``` json
{
  "version": 1,
  "dependencies": {
    "net6.0": {
      "Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[9.0.2.33, )",
        "resolved": "9.0.2.33",
        "contentHash": "gREfQl0/mh22+eV9h8PhCnAwNY5SJswLnUPxvxJwF6L2mhj5pMFMUSvlVke3Gpk94XCrBEyIgHJzFKDiMtA1aw==",
        "dependencies": {
          "Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies": "9.0.2"
        }
      },
      "Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies": {
        "type": "Transitive",
        "resolved": "9.0.2.1",
        "contentHash": "68WUDm0RFg9RjrkxU8cTqc+bRsKa55YkG2SM81rNVMFUtNL56FlGW5gifoaABbR7KU15+myXTA/a+Vqbqc6vQQ=="
      }
    }
  }
}
```

Note the additional dependency on `Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies`.

The lock file generated by 6.2 is compatible with 6.1.



### Verbose Logs

```shell
C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3>..\nuget-6.2.exe restore repro.csproj
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '17.2.1.25201' from 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\bin'.
Restoring packages for C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\repro.csproj...
NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages, nuget.org
WARNING: NU1701: Package 'Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data 9.0.2.33' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1, .NETFramework,Version=v4.6.2, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7.1, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7.2, .NETFramework,Version=v4.8' instead of the project target framework 'net6.0'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project.
Generating MSBuild file C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\obj\repro.csproj.nuget.g.props.
Generating MSBuild file C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\obj\repro.csproj.nuget.g.targets.
Writing assets file to disk. Path: C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\obj\project.assets.json
Failed to restore C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\repro.csproj (in 583 ms).

Errors in C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\repro.csproj
    NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages, nuget.org

NuGet Config files used:
    C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\NuGet\NuGet.Config
    C:\Program Files (x86)\NuGet\Config\Microsoft.VisualStudio.Offline.config

Feeds used:
    C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\
    https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json


C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\NuGet\NuGet.Config:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" protocolVersion="3" />
  </packageSources>
</configuration>

C:\Program Files (x86)\NuGet\Config\Microsoft.VisualStudio.Offline.config:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <add key="Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages" value="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\"/>
  </packageSources>
</configuration>
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Automatic credential plugin discovery is broken when 64 bit msbuild.exe is used by nuget.exe" (#11623) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

6.1

### Worked before?

Yes, with VS 2019 msbuild 

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Configure a project with an azure artifacts feed. 
2. Restore

Expected:
NuGet.exe automatically discovers the plugin shipped with msbuild.

Actual:
NuGet.exe does not automatically discover the plugin shipped with VS. 
The problem is that 64 bit msbuild is used by default and it changes the relative path so pluigin discovery fails. 

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove net45 and net40 targets from the NuGet build" (#11830) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
These are outdated and out of support frameworks.
 
Currently VS 2022 doesn't even give you the option to install the framework components for .NET Framework 4.0 - 4.5.1, which means that you have to jump through hoops to get those targeting packs installed. 

See : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/install/guide-for-developers

> Starting with Visual Studio 2022, Visual Studio no longer includes .NET Framework components for .NET Framework 4.0 - 4.5.1 because these versions are no longer supported. Visual Studio 2022 and later versions can't build apps that target .NET Framework 4.0 through .NET Framework 4.5.1. To continue building these apps, you can use Visual Studio 2019 or an earlier version.

I understand that there are other reasons for targetting net45 in particular, `NuGet.Packaging.Extraction`, but I think that can be addressed by using older versions of the package that have already been published. 

In particular both @drewgillies and @lukka both ran into issues over the last 2 weeks trying to build the product.

* Note that removing these extra frameworks removes 5 different builds, so it'd speed up the build quite a bit.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: nuget.exe doesn't support signatures compressed with deflate method" (#11861) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

6.2.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

We have a local NuGet feed (ProGet) to both store our private packages and move public libraries from nuget.org to our feed.

Somehow, we are getting packages in our internal feed with signature files compressed using the "deflate" method. When we copy .nupkg files from nuget.org to our feed, they are valid. However, for some reason, after some time we are starting to get errors like the following when we are restoring packages from our feed:
```
C:\Nuget\nuget.exe verify -All .\Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg

Verifying Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1
...\Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg

Finished with 1 errors and 0 warnings.
NU3005: The package signature file entry is invalid. The central directory header field 'compression method' has an invalid value (8).
```

It turns out that in a valid .nupkg file, the signature file is not compressed. And in an invalid package, the signature file is compressed using Deflate method.
![valid-invalid](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7262311/172415815-338320bc-5116-4e38-9c67-eaa5ae22b53f.png)

Both signatures, if extracted (unzipped) from the package, are binary equal (you can also see the same CRC on the screenshot). So the problem is that for some reason NuGet does not support signatures compressed with deflate method.

We don't realize yet how it is possible that our package feed "repackages" packages and compresses their signatures, but it seems that nuget.exe should support such signatures since they have a perfectly valid compression method in terms of ZIP file format.

Example of a "broken" package:
[Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/8854398/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg.zip)

### Verbose Logs

_No response_
